key_points: AlgorithmWatch, based in Berlin, was forced to halt its Instagram algorithm research due to legal threats from Facebook.
The project involved a browser plug-in allowing users to share data from their Instagram feeds to analyze algorithm behaviors.
Findings suggested Instagram's algorithm favored images showing bare skin and faces over other content types.
Facebook disputed the project's methodology but initially did not take action.
In May, Facebook accused AlgorithmWatch of violating the platform's terms of service and GDPR for collecting non-consented user data.
Despite defending their data collection practices, AlgorithmWatch shut down the project to avoid potential legal action.
Facebook confirmed contacting AlgorithmWatch about compliance but denied threatening legal action.
Facebook emphasized its willingness to work with researchers in privacy-preserving ways.
The conflict highlights the difficulty of researching social media algorithms due to privacy concerns and platform policies.
AlgorithmWatch criticized Facebook's research data offerings as untrustworthy, continuing concerns of transparency and accountability.
